history.content:
That sounds like a very reasonable and manageable schedule.  I don't know how rigorous your CS background has been so far.  I will say that 61A really heavily tests your ability to apply recursion and higher order functions, and there will be a few fairly tricky homework/lab/exam/project questions that involve good problem solving, the ability to understand HOFs, and the ability to think recursively.  The last 1/3 of the class also heavily teaches Scheme, which is pretty difficult for most students.  But since it seems like you do have some CS background, most other parts of the class, such as basic data structures and basic order of growth, should be straightforward.

If you have taken a linear algebra class before, then the first 1/3 of EE 16A will be a cakewalk.  The middle third will be circuits, which is very difficult at first.  However, the homeworks do a good job of teaching circuits, and so you should be well prepared for any circuits questions on midterms/exams.  The last third of 16A is a bit harder linear algebra because it will be topics that you may have forgotten (QR decomposition, etc).  In my semester, we learned OMP (orthogonal matching pursuit), which was an interesting application of gram-schmidt to recovering sparse signals.  Just knowing the linear algebra itself is not sufficient; you will have to put in some effort to understand the application which they are teaching.

I can't speak to the difficulty of the other two classes, but as a whole it seems like you are setting yourself up to succeed in your first semester.  Welcome to Cal!

Hey y'all.

I have just about zero circuits background past like a week of a Physics-101-type class. So I figure EE16A over EE16B.

I have to take CS47B because my Data Structures course (De Anza) doesn't give full CS61B credit. Looking at it online, I can do most if not all of the 4 assignments+1 research project over the summer, so it won't be much work during the fall!

Is 13 units total (which will really be like 12 units because I won't have CS47B work) a good idea to test the waters a bit? I don't want to find out I'm a Cal-standards idiot by getting shit grades... but maybe it's just not enough, as I've covered at least half of the material in CS61A too.

I only have History, International, and Culture left for my breadth reqs. Knocking one out this first semester with HISTORYC147 seems like a good idea, and I like the subject matter (Renaissance) so hopefully it won't be mindless writing the whole time.

Thanks for any suggestions!
history.subject: How does CS61A, EE16A, CS47B, and HISTORYC157 sound for a F18 transfer schedule?
